affiliation.orgName: Novel Finite-Time Control for Nonstrict Feedback Saturated Nonlinear Systems With Tracking Error Constraint

analytic.title: This article has been accepted for inclusion in a future issue of this journal. Content is final as presented, with the exception of pagination

biblStruct.note: received June 16, 2019; revised October 10, 2019; accepted November 23, 2019.

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.p: This article investigates the neural network-based finite-time control issue for a class of nonstrict feedback nonlinear systems, which contain unknown smooth functions, input saturation, and error constraint. Radial basis function neural networks and an auxiliary control signal are adopted to identify unknown smooth functions and deal with input saturation, respectively. The issue of error constraint is solved by combining the performance function and error transformation. Based on the backstepping recursive technique, a neural network-based finite-time control scheme is developed. The developed control scheme can ensure that the closed-loop system is semi-globally practically finite-time stable. Finally, the validity of theoretical results is verified via simulation studies.

loop issue. In order to solve this issue, two neural networkbased variable-separating control schemes were proposed for nonstrict feedback systems by adopting the monotonically increasing property of bounding functions in [27] and [28]. The investigation in [29] considered the tracking control problem for nonstrict feedback systems, and the validity of the theoretical results was verified via an electromechanical system. However, the proposed methods in [22]- [29] do not consider the issue of finite-time stability.

In general, the finite-time control design is an effective method. The conditions of finite-time stability were presented in [30], which designs a feedback control law for the double integrator without Lipschitz dynamics, and guarantees that the state converges quickly to the equilibrium point. Subsequently, the research on finite-time stability attracted plenty of attention. For example, under the theoretical framework of finite-time stability, two effective control strategies were applied to strict-feedback nonlinear systems in [31] and [32]. Fu et al. [33] proposed a global finite-time control strategy for switched systems by using state-dependent switching signals. Sui et al. [34], [35] and Liu et al. [36] proposed some identification-based finite-time fuzzy control strategies for nonstrict feedback nonlinear systems via the backstepping technique [37] and [38]. Remarkably, the mentioned finite-time control methods in [30]- [38] do not consider the constraint issue.

Recently, some effective constraint control methods were reported [39]- [45]. In the survey of the barrier Lyapunov function-based control method [39]- [43], state variables were constrained via prescribed constants or time-varying functions, while the control signal requires to be rebuilt to ensure the stability of the considered plant, and accommodate the change in the barrier Lyapunov function. In the research of error transformation-based constraint control method [44] and [45], which designs a new virtual error signal via the transformation of the tracking error, so that the constraint issue can be tackled. However, the proposed methods in [39]- [45] do not consider finite-time stability, and the analysis and synthesis of the controller are not applicable for nonstrict feedback saturated nonlinear systems.

The above observations have motivated us to investigate the neural network-based finite-time control issue for nonstrict feedback systems, which simultaneously involve unknown smooth functions, input saturation, and error constraint.
2168-2216 c 2019 IEEE. Personal use is permitted, but republication/redistribution requires IEEE permission.
See http://www.ieee.org/publications_standards/publications/rights/index.html for more information.

Especially, radial basis function neural networks and an auxiliary control signal are adopted to identify unknown smooth functions and deal with input saturation, respectively. The issue of error constraint is solved by combining the performance function and error transformation. Based on the backstepping recursive technique, a neural network-based finite-time control strategy is proposed, and the advantages are summarized as follows.

1) It is noted that the finite-time control methods proposed in [32] and [33] do not consider the error constraint issue, while this article considers this issue, and introduces the performance function and error transformation to solve it. 2) Although some neural network-based backstepping design results were presented in [41] and [42], they are not applicable for nonstrict feedback nonlinear systems with input saturation. This article analyses the stability of nonstrict feedback nonlinear systems and adopts an auxiliary control signal to deal with input saturation.

3) The properties of Gaussian functions are adopted to avoid the algebraic loop problem for nonstrict feedback nonlinear systems. The unknown smooth functions considered in this article are not required to satisfy the monotonically increasing property, i.e.,

, where φ i (•) are of class K-functions, which is a restrictive condition. In addition, the closed-loop system is guaranteed to be semi-globally practically finite-time stable. The rest of this article is summarized as follows. The model description and problem formulation are presented in Section II. The analysis and synthesis of the neural networkbased controller are given for nonstrict feedback saturated nonlinear systems with tracking error constraint in Section III. The simulation results are presented in Section IV. Finally, Section V concludes the main results of this article.

Notations: A continuous function h(•) : [0, d) → [0, ∞) can be seen as a class K-function with h(•) being strictly increasing, and h(0) = 0, where d is a positive constant. R i denotes the i-dimensional Euclidean space. The transpose of a vector is denoted by "T". Euclidean norm for matrices by denoted * .

div.head: II. MODEL DESCRIPTION AND PROBLEM FORMULATION
A. Model Description
div.p: In this article, the nonstrict feedback nonlinear system is described as

where x i ∈ R, i = 1, . . . , n, denote system states, y ∈ R denotes the system output. f i (x), (x = [x 1 , . . . , x n ] T ), i = 1, . . . , n, stand for unknown smooth functions. u ∈ R denotes the control input signal and ω(u) denotes input saturation.
For the saturation nonlinearity of the plant (1), ω(u) is described as
div.formula: ω(u) = sat(u) = sign(u)ω b , |u| ≥ ω b u, |u| < ω b (2)
div.p: where ω b is the bound of ω. On account of (2), we can obtain that when |u| = ω b , there is a sharp corner, and the saturation can be approximated as [46] κ
div.formula: 1 (u) = ω b × tanh u ω b = ω b e u/ω b -e -u/ω b e u/ω b + e -u/ω b . (3
div.p: According to (3), sat(u) in ( 2) is rewritten as
div.formula: sat(u) = κ 1 (u) + κ 2 (u) = ω b × tanh u ω b + κ 2 (u) (4)
div.p: which yields

which means that κ 2 (u) is bounded, and κ 2 (u) increases from 0 to M while |u| changes from 0 to ω b , and κ 2 (u) decreases from M to 0 while |u| is outside of this region. In this article, the following assumption is required. Assumption 1: The system (1) is completely controllable.

div.head: B. RBFNNs
div.p: According to [25] and [26], RBFNNs are well suitable for nonlinear approximations, and unknown smooth functions f i (x) can be identified as
div.formula: f i (x) = T i η i (x) + δ i (x), i = 1, . . . , n(6)
div.p: where i = [ i1 , . . . , il ] T , i = 1, . . . , n, are weights with l > 1 being NN node number, and δ i (x) are minimum approximation errors, η i (x) = [η i1 (x), . . . , η il (x)] T are activation functions, η ij (x) are Gaussian functions as
div.formula: η ij (x) = exp -x -ν ij T x -ν ij 2 ij , j = 1, . . . , l
div.p: where
div.formula: ν ij = [ν 1 ij , . . . , ν n ij ]
div.p: T and ij denote the centers and widths of Gaussian functions, respectively.
The ideal constant weights i are expressed as i = arg min
div.formula: ˆ i ∈U i sup x∈ x ˆ T i η i (x) -f i (x) , 1 ≤ i ≤ n (7
div.p: where U i and x are compact sets for ˆ i and x, respectively. ˆ i are the estimations of i , i = 1, . . . , n.

div.head: C. Finite-Time Stability
div.p: Definition 1 [32]: χ = 0 is the equilibrium point for the plant χ = f (χ ). For any χ(t 0 ), if there exist a setting time T(ε, χ (t 0 )) < ∞ and a positive constant ε so that χ(t) < ε, then the system is semi-globally practically finite-time stable (SGPFS) for t ≥ t 0 + T.
For the analysis of finite-time stability, we need to further introduce the following lemmas.
Lemma 1 [34]: For 0 < ι ≤ 1, and
div.formula: ψ j ∈ R, j = 1, . . . , m, the corresponding inequality holds ⎛ ⎝ m j=1 ψ j ⎞ ⎠ ι ≤ m j=1 ψ j ι ≤ m 1-ι ⎛ ⎝ m j=1 ψ j ⎞ ⎠ ι . (8

div.formula: Consider the differential equation θ1 (t) = -L 1 θ1 (t) + L 2 ϑ 2 (t)
div.p: , where ϑ 2 (t) is a function, and L 1 and L 2 are two positive constants. For any t ≥ t 0 , if ϑ 2 (t) > 0 holds, then one has ϑ 1 (t) ≥ 0 along with the initial condition θ1 (t 0 ) ≥ 0.
Lemma 3 [32]: The following inequality holds:

where θ 1 and θ 2 are two variables, τ 1 , τ 2 , and τ 3 are any positive constants, Lemma 4 [35]: Suppose scalars 0 < β < 1, C > 0, and D > 0, for the plant χ = f (χ ), one has (11) where 0 < < 1, V(χ (0)) denotes the initial value. Then, for any T ≥ T r , the plant χ = f (χ ) is SGPFS.

div.head: D. Performance Function and Error Transformation
div.p: The error constraint can be satisfied by defining the performance function γ (t) : R + → R + /{0} and lim t→∞ γ (t) = γ ∞ with γ (t) being of smooth decreasing property
where γ 0 > 0, γ ∞ > 0, and ρ > 0 are designed constants.
Based on the following constraint conditions, the prescribed bounds of the steady-state and transient can be ensured:
or

where z denotes the tracking error, which will be given later. 0 < λ ≤ 1 is a prescribed scale parameter. The size of the tracking error is confined by the constant γ ∞ in the situation of the steady state. The speed of convergence is regulated by the decreasing rate of γ (t), and values of λγ (0) and γ (0) influence the maximum overshoot and undershoot. Define the converted constraint error q as q(t) = z μ(t) (15) and μ(t) is described as

Proof: The result of 0 < q(t) < 1 is proven by using the prescribed constraint conditions ( 13) and ( 14) with initial condition z(0).
Case 1: For z(0) < 0, the constraint can be produced as -γ (t) < z(t) < λγ (t) from (13).

2) If z(t) < 0, then μ = μ 2 = -λγ (t). Since (z(t)/[-λγ (t)]) > 0, it follows from ( 14) and ( 15) that:

The result of the prescribed constraint conditions ( 13) and ( 14) can be directly obtained by using the aforementioned reverse procedure and 0 < q(t) < 1. Thus, Theorem 1 is proven. Remark 1: Many real-world systems are with tracking error constraint, such as robot systems and nonlinear coupled heat temperature systems.

div.formula: C = min β c, c D = n-1 m=1 m i=1 1 2 ξ i l + n-1 m=1 m i=1 1 2 δ * 2 i + n i=1 1 2 i ξ 2 i + n i=1 1 2 δ * 2 i + 1 2 M 2 + (1 -β)β β 1-β + nal
div.p: and combining with Lemma 1, one has
div.formula: Vn ≤ -CV β n + D. (77
div.p: Based on the aforementioned results, we obtain Theorem 2. Theorem 2: For the plant (1), under Assumptions 1 and 2, design virtual control inputs (34) and (50), the actual control input (68), adaptation functions ( 35), (51), and (69). Then the proposed control scheme has the following properties.
1) The closed-loop system is SGPFS.
2) The error z of the controlled system arrives at a small neighborhood of the origin in finite time.
3) The error z remains in a prescribed bound. Proof:
1) It follows from (77) that:
div.formula: Vn (χ ) ≤ -CV β n (χ ) -(1 -)CV β n (χ ) + D (78) where 0 < < 1, χ = [ς 1 , . . . , ς n , ξ1 , . . . , ξn ] T . Let χ = {χ |V β n (χ ) ≤ (D/[(1 -)C])} and ¯ χ = {χ |V β n (χ ) > (D/[(1 -)C])}. If χ ∈ ¯ χ , then one has Vn (χ ) ≤ -CV β n (χ ). (79
div.p: Taking integral on both sides of (79) from 0 to t, one has
div.formula: t 0 Vn (χ ) V β n (χ ) dτ ≤ - t 0 Cdτ (80) which yields 1 1 -β V 1-β n (χ (t)) - 1 1 -β V 1-β n (χ (0)) ≤ -Ct. (81
div.p: according to (81), one has χ ∈ χ for t ≥ T r and stays there.
Then the closed-loop system is SGPFS.
2) Subsequently, from the definition of V n , for t ≥ T r , one has

which implies that the tracking error of the controlled system can converge to a small neighborhood of the origin in the finite time T r , the size of the tracking error can be arbitrarily small from the definition of C, D, β, and parameters chosen in the performance function (12). In addition, according to the definition of V n , for t ≥ T r , we have
div.formula: n i=1 1 2 ς 2 i ≤ V n ≤ D (1 -)C 1 β which yields ς i (i = 1, . . . , n) are bounded, and ς i ∈ {ς i ||ς i | ≤ 2(D/[(1 -)C]) (1/β) }.
div.p: Similarly, for t ≥ T r , we have
div.formula: n i=1 1 2 ξ 2 i ≤ V n ≤ D (1 -)C 1 β which yields ξi (i = 1, . . . , n) are bounded, and ξi ∈ { ξi || ξi | ≤ 2(D/[(1 -)C]) (1/β) }.
div.p: 3) For t > 0, given 0 < q(0) < 1, and q(t) is continuous, we can obtain 0 < q(t) < 1, and one has |z| < |μ|. Hence, the constraint error signal z remains in the prescribed bounded set

div.head: IV. SIMULATION STUDIES
div.p: The validity of the presented control strategy is confirmed through simulation results.
Example 1: Consider the following nonstrict feedback nonlinear system:
where f 1 (x 1 , x 2 ) = x 1 e -0.1x 2 2 and f 2 (x 1 , x 2 ) = sin(0.5x 1 x 2 ). For the plant (84), the input saturation ω(u) (with ω b = 4) is described by
div.formula: ω(u) = sat(u) = sign(u)ω b , |u| ≥ ω b u, |u| < ω b . (85
div.p: Choose the reference signal as y d (t) = sin(t), and define the performance function γ (t) as

The parameters are chosen as c 1 = 0.3, c 2 = 20, 1 = 2 = 0.01, a = 0.01, β = 0.9, γ 0 = 10, γ ∞ = 0.7, ρ = 0.5, and λ = 0.9. Select the initial values as ξ1 (0) = 0.05, ξ2 (0) = 0.2, x 1 (0) = 0.095, x 2 (0) = 0.01, and s(0) = 0. The simulation results of the presented control strategy in this article are given in Figs. 12345, where the trajectories of y and y d are shown in Fig. 1. Fig. 2 shows the response of the system state x 2 . Fig. 3 shows the error z with prescribed bound. The control signal u is shown in Fig. 4. The input saturation ω(u) is given in Fig. 5.

It is clearly shown that although there exist input saturation and error constraint in the system (84), the control signal still ensures the stability of the closed-loop system. From Figs. 12345, it is clearly shown that the proposed NNbased finite-time control approach is effective.

It is noted that if the approach presented in this article does not consider the prescribed performance, then it reduces the control approach in [29]. To show the effectiveness of the presented approach in this article, we use the approach proposed in [29] to control the robot manipulator with the inclusion of input saturation (84), and choose the same parameters as the above simulation studies. The simulation results are shown in Fig. 6, but the prescribed performance of the error cannot be achieved. Example 2: Consider a robot manipulator model with input saturation [18]. The dynamic equation of this system is described by
div.formula: qs + Bq s + Mgl sin(q s ) = ω(u) (87
div.p: where q s , qs , and qs denote the angle of the rigid link, angular velocity, and angular acceleration, respectively. = 2 kg • m 2 denotes the rotation inertia of the motor, g = 10 N/kg denotes the gravitational acceleration, l = 1 m denotes the distance between the joint axis and mass center, B = 2 N • s/m denotes the damping coefficient, M = 1 kg denotes the mass of the rigid link. By defining x 1 = q s and x 2 = qs , the (87) can be re-expressed as
where f 1 (x 1 , x 2 ) = 0, f 2 (x 1 , x 2 ) = -(Mgl/ ) sin(x 1 )-(B/ )x 2 . For the plant (88), the input saturation ω(u) (with ω b = 3.3) is described by
div.formula: ω(u) = sat(u) = sign(u)ω b , |u| ≥ ω b u, |u| < ω b . (89
div.p: Choose the reference signal as y d (t) = sin(t), and define the performance function γ (t) as

The parameters are chosen as c 1 = 0.04, c 2 = 10, 1 = 2 = 0.02, a = 0.02, β = 0.95, γ 0 = 10, γ ∞ = 0.65, ρ = 0.55, and λ = 0.6. Select the initial values as ξ1 (0) = 0.04, ξ2 (0) = 0.3, x 1 (0) = 0.08, x 2 (0) = 0.02, and s(0) = 0. The simulation results of the presented control strategy in this article are given in Figs. [7][8][9][10][11], where the trajectories of y and y d are shown in Fig. 7. Fig. 8 shows the response of the system state x 2 . Fig. 9 shows the tracking error z with prescribed bound. The control signal u is shown in Fig. 10. The input saturation ω(u) is given in Fig. 11.
From Figs. 7-11, it is clearly shown that the proposed NN-based finite-time control approach is effective.

div.head: V. CONCLUSION
div.p: The NN-based finite-time control issue has been investigated for nonstrict feedback saturated nonlinear systems with tracking error constraint in this article. By designing the new virtual error variable, the error constraint issue is solved. Based on the approximation property of RBFNNs and an auxiliary control signal, the analysis and synthesis of the controller are given. It is proved that the closed-loop is SGPFS, and the tracking performance with the prescribed bound is guaranteed. Inspired by some elegant works [47]- [50], our future study topics will focus on the finite-time controller design for nonlinear distributed parameter systems with prescribed performance.

div.head: ACKNOWLEDGMENT
div.p: The authors are grateful to the Editor-in-Chief, an Associate Editor, and anonymous reviewers for their constructive comments based on which the presentation of this article has been greatly improved.

This work was supported in part by the Self-Planned Task of State Key Laboratory of Robotics and Systems of Harbin Institute of Technology under Grant SKLRS201801A03, in part by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under Grant 61873311, and in part by the 111 Project under Grant B16014. This article was recommended by Associate Editor M. Basin.
